lines.text: [pointing to male dressing room]

[to Victor]
Listen - I've put your trousers on, but I'm not going to take them off in *there*!

[He leans towards her as they sit on the bed]
You've given me an idea.

[nervously]
Have I?

[leans closer]
You can do something for me.

[looking apprehensive]
Can I?

[eagerly]
Take off those pyjamas.

[appalled]
*What*?
Put this on!
[he produces a slinky dress and high-heeled boots and sits down with his back turned]
Now I tell you what we'll do...

[affronted]
Thanks very much!
You want to be an actress, don't you? You want a chance to show what you can do...
[her eyes begin to shine as she finally understands]
...you've got it. You're going to take my place at Cruft's Music Hall tonight!
I'm not going. I can't do it.
Do what?
I can't be a man all my life!
But you'll have time off. And you can knit and knit to your heart's content...
But think what you're asking me!

[gazes upward as he quotes]
"There's a tide in the affairs of men" -
[descending temporarily to earth]
Tides go out - don't they?
This'll be a spring one!
[Takes her by the shoulders]
We'll carry everything before us. I'll never leave you - and I'll never let you down.
[They shake hands on it as a smile spreads from her face to his]

[to Robert]
You have an unclean mind.
I've been father, mother, sister and brother to that girl - and nothing more.

[watching 'Bill' on stage]
Isn't he marvelous?

[absently]
Adorable...
*What*?

[hastily]
Er... marvelous.

[Of Victor, who is busy dancing with Robert's fiancée]
He's quite harmless - he's Shakespearing her to death.

[to 'Bill', about Princess Mironoff]
She doesn't know you. Smile!
[Bill smiles awkwardly at the Princess, Victor does so with broad masculine appreciation]

[aside]
Not like *that*. A he-man smile; she's beautiful!
[Bill catches sight of the handsome Robert and her smile widens]

[acidly]
I said the Princess, not the Prince...

[calculatingly]
We have dinner late and then decide to motor on. The car will conveniently break down - there.
That's original!
We... we then, walk, three kilometres.
Now don't get too original, darling.

Well, what's three kilometres on a nice moonlight night? At the end of that walk, by chance, we will arrive at an inn, which, by a strange coincidence I know well. I shall telephone the "patron" and make some interesting reservations.
